You can backup manually by copying the key in the debug menu. Automatically the keys are put in apple keychain and stored with your apple id. That means if you lose your device or wipe it, or even just delete the app, the key information stays around and your identity is there for when you install. There's a bit of re-syncing that happens upon a fresh install. We basically store both your key and the sequence number of your most recent message. Until you get all of your messages downloaded we don't let you write to your log to avoid forking your feed.

# Marã Robdzuri - Planting in the Forest

![grupo-canteiro.jpg](&Hk0D3vER80GOnTw5Non3mAfgUwgCkCPMI0L+TfwRloY=.sha256)
*Xavante women practicing agroforestry at the Flor de Ibez Institute*

> TL&DR Interethnic experiential training project in agroforestry and sustainable practices looking for donations, check out at  [their page](http://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&sl=auto&tl=en_us&u=https://flordeibez.org/flor/projeto-mara-robdzuri/)

Last year me and [@Isabela](@Xe+wuSGAaEdwgyI/ql2WVgPG64Mqf8tVHU0VXne9Ki8=.ed25519) stayed almost 4 months at the [Flor de Ibez Institute](https://flordeibez.org/), which thought us so much about agroforestry, use and maintenance of tools (I learned the chainsaw 💛 ) and just overall living.

Together we wrote a project for continuing their interactions with the [Xavante people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xavante_people), but unfortunately didn't  get funded. This year they decided, with all possible care, to continue moving despite #covid19 and any other grants, but thru donations.

The Xavante have been decimated and their cultured almost disintegrated by missionaries in the 40's and  50's (and still today). But they resist proud and with a wish for revival. Unfortunately because most of their lands have been taken, they no longer have #foodsovereignty, and it's becoming less and less viable for them to practice their traditional slash-and-burn methods of agriculture. So agroforestry techniques are very important for them to be empowered and regain their autonomy. And that's the focus of this project, which I can vow for.

The Xavante are the guardians of the Savanna and of the Amazon, so empowering them is defending the Earth.

If this is something that resonates with you, please read more about the [project](http://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&sl=auto&tl=en_us&u=https://flordeibez.org/flor/projeto-mara-robdzuri/) (which I passed thru Google translate), and [donate using Paypal](https://www.paypal.com/signin?forceLogin=false&returnUri=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.paypal.com%2Fdonate&state=%253Ftoken%253DoErjYNKPUn9QcPWsxDFgBcL-_KGFj43N9V8m_H5E08lNkZ8pUM8KpPZ2BuYdvry-8hQcB9_nDDJfDDN7%2526fromUL%253Dtrue&intent=donate&ctxId=6d33ca4dccc646a8b427cbea8d683367). They are only asking for R$ 6900,00 or 1270.00 USD to continue on.

Hey i'd love to try out some of the tools you've been working on. We've got a couple dozen mutual aid collectives coordinating a bunch of movement work and some better tools would be good.

One issue which comes up is how to protect user privacy and also have it be non-public. We're facing a lot of problems with right wing extremists disrupting our online organizing but also regular physical attacks on our protests and events. It's gotten so bad that every activist has gone through bullet wound first responder training, we all carry bullet wound kits, and wear ballistic vests at protests. We had to crowd fund to raise money for equipment, as the vests are a couple hundred dollars each. We're also facing a bunch of attacks where trump supporters drive their vehicles in to the crowd, or just sometimes [randomly tries to kill people who they think are leftists](https://news.google.com/search?q=portland%20hit%20and%20run&hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen). 

So we need a way of vetting who can post, edit, volunteer, and to make it so even seeing what's happening isn't public. 

We're using signal for coordination and [signal boost](https://github.com/team-friendo/signalboost) for alerts. 

I even have a nifty domain, civic.love...
i don't like the forking behavior and in Planetary we just flatten the replies. I find the forked replies annoying, unless somebody did the work of making it make sense the way reddit does.

Is it possible to just make it all private to registered users? We don't need complicated permissions, just not display everything public and approval of who can get in... i guess it could be as simple as http auth basic even...

![Planetary - Social media for Humans](&D2FRqSepVoRdo3hKoX0Q8h7+DuH3HSlNusdCfl/TNCk=.sha256)

Planetary, the decentralized social media app based on the Secure Scuttlebutt protocol is in the App Store. And we have a favor to ask:

Would you please go and give us an upvote on Product Hunt? It will really help us get the attention of new users, press, and investors. [Comment and upvote on product hunt](https://www.producthunt.com/posts/planetary-bcedec54-a0eb-4d1b-b1ec-d423300a2b15)

Our dream for years (and years!) had been to build an easy to use, protocol-based, decentralized social media app, and it is thrilling that it is a reality. We still have work to do, but this is an incredible milestone.

Planetary is built on the idea that communities should manage public space as a commons instead of asking corporations or the state to regulate our social norms. When we started building Planetary the idea that users should own their relationships and accounts seemed like a radical notion.

![Planetary - Create your own communiity](&ezV2OSp+8JvxLz1ypMge4zUxbtVra3ZmXPIXfHHlFT4=.sha256)

### "technical solutions to social problems."
There’s a joke that what we’re doing as technologists is looking for technical solutions to social problems. That’s so often what we expect of startups and the Silicon Valley ethos. But that’s not how social software works, it’s about people.

When I wanted to learn about what went wrong with social media I had the immense privilege of being invited to spend time with the Center for Civic Media at the MIT Media Lab. At the lab [Dr Nathan Matias](https://natematias.com/) was [researching subreddit governance](https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/governing-human-and-machine-behavior-in-an-experimenting-society/). He found that the strongest communities depended on a combination of tools and social norms.

We need solutions which combine technology and people. We need digital spaces which reflect the social norms which work in the offline world. We know what’s acceptable behavior based on mimicry of others and social context and the collapsing social context is one of many problems with our existing system.

![Social Media Browser](&7s1yZ24Q6BPaPMejpu4bSXq/2Bb7VPdCb8wuUPZXA1g=.sha256)

### Everything old is new again
Back when we were creating Twitter, I remember thinking that humans evolved over hundreds of thousands of years as social creatures, but it’s only in the last few millennia that technology has shaped us. Our tools evolve quickly but we evolve slowly. When we develop new tools, we use them to do the same kinds of things we've always done, but now with different affordances. Instead of flirting with somebody from the next tribe over, we flirt with somebody who’s in the same cultural tribe halfway around the world.

With twitter the idea was, make something so easy, simple, fluid, that you can keep in touch with the happenings of your friends lives without running into them walking down the street. It gives users a sense of intimacy with celebrities in a way that was never possible before, but the human behavior is the same. That casual social space has connected people around the world and become the central public sphere of news and politics.

We manage social norms based on where we are, the built environment and customs shape how we act. That’s how we know to act differently in a library or a bar or a busy market. Often we have guides who help people learn the cultural norms of the space, like librarians both explaining how to use the library and shushing people who don’t follow the rules.

When twitter created a flat space, made it so you could casually follow the lives of millions, it didn’t reproduce that sense of space. With planetary we’re building tools which help you get context and connect. We believe these tools we’ve built, and will continue to evolve with empower community self governance.

![Building a commons together](&Z+Xp1k+k7GXfs7Oi2WzgKVlMuNQgeRwyKwWn4RLcGu0=.sha256)

### Building a digital commons
We’re using a model of a commons, it’s a shared resource not owned by anyone but managed by the participants for the benefit of all participants. A commons isn’t doomed to fall apart, in despite being peer reviewed, Tragedy of the Commons, was a fable without basis in evidence created by a racist nazi eugenicist.

In reality the commons is a viable social-political-economic model. [Elinor Ostrom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elinor_Ostrom), the first woman to win the Nobel Prize in Economics, studied the commons and what makes them successful. She outlined the characteristics of a well run commons. We’ve strived to incorporate her eighth qualities of a successful commons into Planetary:

* Clearly defined (clear definition of the contents of the common pool resource and effective exclusion of external un-entitled parties);
* The appropriation and provision of common resources that are adapted to local conditions;
* Collective-choice arrangements that allow most resource appropriators to participate in the decision-making process;
* Effective monitoring by monitors who are part of or accountable to the appropriators;
* A scale of graduated sanctions for resource appropriators who violate community rules;
* Mechanisms of conflict resolution that are cheap and of easy access;
* Self-determination of the community recognized by higher-level authorities; and
* In the case of larger common-pool resources, organization in the form of multiple layers of nested enterprises, with small local commons at the base level.

Both Planetary and the underlying protocols are designed based on Ostrom’s research. We believe, and evidence shows, that these principles provide for creating a healthy online public space where people can be empowered to address hate speech and harassment with community organizing, mutual aid, self governance, and tools.

Planetary won't end hate speech, but it will give us a new model distinct from asking for state intervention or companies to do a better job of regulating us. One of our community members and Mozilla fellow, [@emmi bevensee’s](@5fX6QTmue/udf7tLwW25vQ63wZSENrksghBt6vfL4/I=.ed25519) report on combating hate groups in a decentralized erais an excellent read if you’re excited about questions like this.

![Planetary](&ZbJkvU7bmDwXjYu6w3TIgY+0AbDCF8r81UsQSGgyB7s=.sha256)


### Acknowledgements:
I want to thank everybody who works on this and has worked on it. [@amandabee](@a9fJ2HzsGGq8lMsnag00cPRbhLWWtki3HIU9fegzGDg=.ed25519), Tom Coates, Christoph Moskalonek, [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519), [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519), [@Sebastian Heit](@a+PqJTSfL3nZjmU5/MNWuAFRqHQAZgb5qQ0jGlxurPE=.ed25519), [@Martin](@zGgptLCCP0pfM//7ll0SuJorn0dMEvY4aaM2pu0fDzk=.ed25519), [@Kris](@g6c1/Zywct6TZsff4z26g24ax5HYmGvun7e3qT/yIPg=.ed25519) have all poured immense energy into this project. The protocol Planetary is based in, Secure Scuttlebutt was started by [@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519)
and has had hundreds of contributors around the world. Without them we wouldn’t be here today. Beyond just SSB, our work exists within a much larger ecosystem of work on the decentralized web and we want to thank the Internet Archive, Mozilla, and Aspiration Tech for their indispensable work in support of this space. The Center for Civic Media at the MIT Media Lab was kind enough to include me as a researcher and that work has shaped the design and vision of planetary, I’m boundlessly grateful to Sasha Costanza-Chock and Ethan Zuckerman for their work and support. Without the support and encouragement of our investors, James, Roy, and Minn at Bloomberg Beta, Chris at Fuel Capital, Kent at Upside, Consensus Coven, Erik and Niraj at Kilowatt, Balaji, Blaine Cook, Biz Stone, and many others, we wouldn’t have been able to get this far.

### Introduce Yourself!

It's a [scuttlebutt](https://scuttlebutt.nz/) tradition to use the #newpeople hashtag to introduce yourself an get to know folks. It's our hello world. 

### Talk to the planetary team

Discord: https://dsc.gg/planetary

Matrix: https://matrix.to/#/%23planetary%3Amatrix.org

Support: https://planetarysupport.zendesk.com/hc/en-us

Bugs & Code Issues: https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/issues

We can't do this without you.

### Protocols not Platforms.

Planetary is an implementation of [the secure scuttlebutt protocol](https://ssbc.github.io/scuttlebutt-protocol-guide/). There are a bunch of talks and [docs](https://scuttlebutt.nz/docs/) about how it works and how you can contribute. There have been a number of [academic papers on the protocol and technology](https://scuttlebutt.nz/docs/research/). 

### [Scuttlebutt Principals & Values](https://scuttlebutt.nz/docs/principles/)

Scuttlebutt aims to harmonize four perspectives of life: __Environment__ reflecting __Technology__ reflecting __Community__ reflecting __Society__.

We acknowledge the natural, the virtual, and the social environments. Our responsibility is to recognize which resources are __abundant__, which are __sufficient__, and adapt accordingly through __efficiency__.

Technology is simply the means by which we communicate. We use __local-first__ publishing so that each person owns their words and actions. Our solutions are piecemeal __upgradeable__, replaceable and incrementally improvable. Tending and pruning are not a stranger’s duty, it is through __near moderation__ and free listening that we improve our surroundings. Infrastructure is a voluntary act, __multimodal welcoming__ is how we on-board people via diverse connectivity modes (technological acts of inclusion) as well as with greetings (words of inclusion). No one “signs up” but everyone is invited.

Our community is a web of friendships: relationships defined not by a follow button, but by the flexibility of __subjectivity__. We cherish the freedom to be __independent__, but it is this same freedom which encourages – not coerces – us to be __interdependent__. We know we can at any time fork, but when individually recognizing the whole being greater than the sum of its parts, we tend to develop the collective. We value disagreement when it’s supportive, and see it as generative and bond forming.

Society is not made of homogeneous people, so we must allow __pluralism__ of cultures to flourish. The edges of the social graph must extend to include all people and their diverse values, interactions, and customs. No one of us can build a welcoming place for all groups, because the very concept of welcoming is subjective. Instead, removing ourselves as arbiters of other communities, we must design platforms that are easy to re-design.

![ssbprinciples.png](&aa1EpqWpJScPW8UjAkbi2MrwFKbGc0N2m1Pyz2Vgx3U=.sha256)

[@Manuj](@pHUl08IivpAHPd1nCaWnxAmrTbBBI2VH30KKtdgDsFM=.ed25519)  Right now planetary does not support rooms, ebt (partial feeds), routing connections over to, or dht invites. It will directly connect to users on the same local network. We hope to add all of those features in the future. We're also super excited about private groups, edit through #ssb-crut and tangles, and #sameas for single identities supporting multiple devices.

We also would like to support Android. But we're lucky that it's an open protocol and [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) has [manyverse](https://www.manyver.se/) for everybody to use.

We're actually going to put up a section on our website directing folks to Manyverse, patchwork, oasis a options because we get so many questions about non-ios apps. And we're just like, this is an open ecosystem, you're not dependent on just planetary, that's whole point.

I wish we had marketing people, but it's just me. 

A couple of things. First off we have forks of a lot of ssb code because we use it, we added modifications, and either by license or social contract, we're releasing the code back out. No ssb implementation perfectly supports everything. In particular we're running an older version of go-ssb and much to [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519)'s chagrin, commented out some of the validation steps for other people's feeds. If i were a better programmer i'd have found a better solution.

Marketing text, yep it's super hard to communicate in few words a complicated system and set of ideas. We have an [FAQ](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/wiki/What-Is-Planetary) which lays out the details about how it works and we link to  [scuttlebutt.nz](https://scuttlebutt.nz/) and a bunch of other ssb documentation. Users respond to different things than developers. We tested and tried various versions of the website which focused more on the underlying tech and people hated it.  We fully intend to take advantage of the current interest in changing social media. Current SSB users are not our target audience. 

If you don't like how we're doing things, planetary is open source, feel free to fork it, build your own version to release, promoted how you'd like.

Yes, in scuttlebutt by default follow, unfollow, and block messages are public. It's possible to do private messages just to yourself or to a group of people and put those contact messages in there. Patchwork does this as an option but it's not part of Planetary yet.

Today i'm working to see about improving the display of likes but also contact messages so you can see when somebody followed / blocked / unfollowed. The primary purpose is to expose to users what's happening with contacts to discover new people to follow or block. It also helps showing you what's visible to others.

One of the coolest things I've learned so far while working with #digital-democracy has been about the work being done with the [Earth Defenders Toolkit](https://www.earthdefenderstoolkit.com/).

I'm still trying to understand the scope of the project, and it's still being born, but it seems to have lots to do with the work I've been doing with [Connecting Peoples of the Earth](%hMC/Ix/mnDvk0KYGcvXGo/Kt8UuegWYz6vB91RyhIKQ=.sha256), specially in regards to testing tools that assist in satisfying needs of indigenous communities, adapting them, making documentation on how to use them, and making them available through the [community server/portal](%cFBwesb+eIIVMd6vF8jptiklEr9lyWENl9e/k2tMikY=.sha256).

During an interview with the guys working with EDT they asked me about the needs that the communities had, that we might assist satisfying. These were the ones that came to mind, regarding the Krahô villages I visited, and the input they gave me:

1. **Need for tools/methodologies assisting them on co-buying food, tools and materials**: currently they are locked into buying stuff from local businesses that sell them terrible products at very high prices; cobuying could lead to improving their health and their financial security.

2. **Need for tools/methodologies assisting them on co-selling their products** (crafts, extractivism, stories, knowledge, etc): currently only the largest village (Pedra Branca) has organized their production and selling of crafts, which has given the women huge financial (and overall) autonomy, but with great effort during years; tools and methodologies for spreading that effort and reducing the barriers would be very empowering.

3. **Need for tools/methodologies that could assist them with their finances**: currently they leave their govt aid credit cards with the local businesses, which leads to financial imprisonment, and individualistic buying behavior; financial empowered brings community empowerment.  

4. **Need for tools/methodologies/training material dealing with food-sovereignty**: the word about the efficiency of agroforesting techniques has gone far and has reached every indigenous group that I'm in touch with, unfortunately the way these techniques are thought by people coming from western culture are hard for them to grasp and agroforests are complex systems that are sometimes hard to manage; so training materials made by the peoples for the peoples, and maybe tools to assist in managing such food-systems could assist them regaining food-sovereignty which has been lost since their lands have been taken and reduced to small reserves.

For **1** I remember talking to [@Dan](@BRJjWQp7mI8stCgpFJGwrUhfqMH3Mewy7E7FHsEaaXA=.ed25519) at Scuttlecamp about [Cobuy](https://github.com/root-systems/cobuy), which they worked at #root-systems. Unfortunately is seems to have been discontinued. Anyone else aware of any other FOSS system for co-buying?

For **2** I thought on having a Wordpress with WooCommerce shop running on the local-server, and using a plugin such as [this](https://wordpress.org/plugins/wpsitesynccontent/) to sync between offline/online sites. A communal shop and maybe some well made spreadsheets could help them out. Any other ideas?

For **3** and **4** I still have no ideas... Any input is welcome.

# Ferramentas para mapeamento e monitoramento territorial

## Xingu+

Usa satélite Sirad X e outras fontes para mapear degradação, incêndios, etc no corredor do Xingu.

- [Plataforma](https://xingumais.org.br/observatorios/degradacao)
- [Dados](https://geo.socioambiental.org/xingu/)

## Somai

Plataforma online com dados científicos sobre as Terras Indígenas da Amazônia brasileira, que busca mostrar a importância destes territórios para ações de mitigação das mudanças climáticas e manutenção do equilíbrio ambiental regional.

- [Plataforma](http://somai.org.br/plataforma/)
- [Dados](http://api.somai.org.br/v1/ti/21501/focus_by_year?id=21501&type=FocosCalor)

## Global Forest Watch

Global Forest Watch (GFW) é uma plataforma online que fornece dados e ferramentas para o monitoramento de florestas. Usando tecnologia de ponta, o GFW permite que qualquer pessoa acesse informações quase em tempo real sobre onde e como as florestas estão mudando em todo o mundo.

- [Plataforma](https://www.globalforestwatch.org/map)
- [Dados](https://data.globalforestwatch.org/)
- [Tutorial de uso](https://resource-watch.github.io/doc-api/tutorials.html)

## Global Forest Change

As florestas em todo o mundo estão em um estado de fluxo, com perdas cada vez maiores em algumas regiões e ganhos em outras. Hansen et al. (p. 850) examinou os dados globais do Landsat em uma resolução espacial de 30 metros para caracterizar a extensão, perda e ganho da floresta de 2000 a 2012. Globalmente, 2,3 milhões de quilômetros quadrados de floresta foram perdidos durante o período de estudo de 12 anos e 0,8 milhões quilômetros quadrados de nova floresta foram ganhos. Os trópicos exibiram tanto as maiores perdas quanto os maiores ganhos (por meio de rebrota e plantio), com perdas superando os ganhos.

- [Plataforma](http://earthenginepartners.appspot.com/science-2013-global-forest)
- [Dados](http://earthenginepartners.appspot.com/science-2013-global-forest/download_v1.7.html)

## Collect Earth

Collect Earth é uma ferramenta que permite a coleta de dados através do Google Earth. Em conjunto com o Google Earth, Bing Maps e Google Earth Engine, os usuários podem analisar imagens de satélite de alta e muito alta resolução para uma ampla variedade de finalidades, incluindo:

 

Apoiar Inventários Florestais Nacionais multifásicos

Avaliações de Uso da Terra, Mudança de Uso da Terra e Florestas (LULUCF)

Monitoramento de terras agrícolas e áreas urbanas

Validação de mapas existentes

Coleta de dados socioeconômicos espacialmente explícitos

Quantificando desmatamento, reflorestamento e desertificação

 

Sua facilidade de uso e curva de aprendizado suave tornam-no uma ferramenta perfeita para realizar avaliações rápidas, precisas e econômicas. É altamente personalizável para as necessidades e metodologias específicas de coleta de dados.

 

Os dados coletados por meio do Collect Earth são exportáveis para formatos comumente usados e também podem ser exportados para o Saiku, uma ferramenta que facilita a análise de dados.

- [Plataforma](http://www.openforis.org/tools/collect-earth.html)

![world_population_density.jpg](&S5rwfTQXV1AHhRJFh57uypy4YojLzf1FTnj2fR757x8=.sha256)

*[source](https://gfw.global/3sZiO4v)*

And now a world population density map, to contrast. In the territories known as USA, Brasil and Australia the parts that are densely populated are exactly the ones with less community and indigenous lands. Interestingly Mexico is very populated and packed with communities.

![analise_avanco_terrotorio.jpg](&XawamK/8sX+U9SGnJpYBpiG0jqp62Z5pUEy5ts8e+zE=.sha256)

*[source](https://gfw.global/3rpbBtV)*

## Analysis

A closer look at South America, more specifically at the race towards the amazon from the south-east of brasil, the west of peru, bolivia and paraguai and south of colombia and venezuela.

Layering lots of data sets together and using the feature that shows the expansion of deforestation over time we can understand the paths that are opening. It's like a disease taking over a body.

The arrow points to around where I'm at, which is suppose to be an island of preservation but just a small part actually still is. Besides these small islands of green which are usually parks, the eastern part of brasil has been taken by mono cultures.

This has happened specially to the savanna, which is the part with no purple (biodiversity integrity) around the arrow where I live. With the savanna taken the next frontier is the Amazon rain forest, because the preserved part in the north-east is not-desired *[Caatinga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caatinga)* (shrub-land). Many routes are being made deeper into the Amazon and they widen at accelerating speed.

It's quite the contrary from what humans have been doing for at least the past 11 thousand years, which was [contributing to the formation of the Amazon](https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2020/04/200408110336.htm). The cultures that descend from those who formed the Amazon are still around and form today the front-lines for defense of one of the most amazing technologies ever developed.

Technologies such as these are starting to be valued today and branded as things like *permaculture* or *agroforestry* for example. If we continued the work that was being done pre-invsasion we should actually be expanding the forest into the savanna. And this could be happening today, but the contrary is, and there seems to be little hope for a reversal.

To the south-east of brasil, where everything was already lost, the simulation seems to point that regeneration through [silviculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silviculture) (wasn't familiar with the term) is happening. But as I've driven a lot around these areas, I can tell that they're calling eucalyptus mono-cultures "regenerative", which is bs.

## Conclusion

I believe three strategies need to be adopted to safe-guard and expand the Amazon:
1. Strengthen the communities which are at the front-lines ⚠️ **most immediate** ⚠️
1. Scale initiatives to re-forest mono cultures and re-populate them with earth-culture communities
1. Create expanding barriers around the communities that are in the front-lines, learning and adapting tools and methodologies developed from item 2 initiatives

Of course this a super-hyper simplification of things, and each of these tasks are an epic on their own. The grand-challenge really seems to be in decolonizing in the non-metaphorical sense: finding legal/financial ways to return lands to be cared by originary cultures, or at least a harmonious mixture of ancestral knowledge and emerging regenerative technologies. Reminds me of #undomination.

> Humans then cut back anything trying to grow on their mounds, and cultivated the soil, making it more fertile. Then they died, so the forest just did what it usually does and sent those nutrients straight up to the sky.

I still don't fully agree with that. They were planting species that grew into huge trees, and in many cases would  only start producing a generation later. To me it seems they were generating food-forests on purpose. Raising mounds and producing crops like corn, cassava and squash, but also planting trees for nuts, spiritual medicine, lumber, etc. And those domesticated trees are all over the amazon still today.

> I think the rest of us humans should cultivate the soil like that, even if we don’t grow forests, since it prevents crop failure. And then if we die or move on, we’ll leave the land better off than we found it.

As far as I can tell, growing forests is the most productive (mid-long term) way of growing anything, and the best way to fight the climate crisis. I've yet not found something that makes so much sense.

It’s funny that you don’t know much about Uruguay from a European perspective because it’s very European. In fact it has it’s own elected members of the Italian parliament and a majority of the population has EU citizenship. 

When Spanish and Italian elections happen all the political parties from Spain and Italy have offices, rallies, signs, voting drives, etc.... people of course vote for the local Uruguayan government as well. 

Uruguay is like a Nordic political system with mostly people from Southern Europe located in South America. It’s is by far the most secular country in the Western Hemisphere. Nobody knows much about it other than Uruguayans are in obsessed with fútbol. 

Until the 1950’s it was a major destination for immigrants but then the Latin American economic crises hit and there was a dictatorship in the 70’s and 80’s. Since the last economic crisis in 2002 the country has steadily become more wealthy again and now is receiving new waves of immigrants. 

I should write up some posts about Uruguay beyond just sending pictures of the ocean, sunsets, and mate.

# Connecting peoples of the Earth: Tukano

continued from %hMC/Ix/mnDvk0KYGcvXGo/Kt8UuegWYz6vB91RyhIKQ=.sha256

Beginning of 2020 a couple contacted me. They had heard of me, from someone here from SSB (if I'm not mistaken) whose on their network. They were Philippe Greier and [Naiara Tukano](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZHXx2lNFA4c). An unusual couple, a *gringo* and an indigenous lawyer, daughter of one of the most representative indigenous leaders from the Amazon.

They were looking for ways to connect the [Balaio Indigenous Territory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balaio_Indigenous_Territory), one of the many territories the [Tukano people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tukano_people) call home, and also home to other peoples such as the Baniwa, Baré, Koripako and Tariana. The territory has no way to communicate with the outside world, and road access is a real nightmare from what they tell me.

They were the original inspiration for the **Connecting peoples of the Earth** project, as the [initial image](http://localhost:8989/blobs/get/&2c/C6npkznEJV4G9bZl43oo22teNGm/uZUcCDsKCGfE=.sha256?) I shared was actually a plan for their region. So for the past year we've been writing grant proposals together, without any luck, until late 2020 they confirmed funding together with the [Nova Era Institute](http://www.institutonovaera.org.br/).

Naiara and Philippe had already started what they call "Project Tukano" years before, visiting communities and gathering information on what the peoples most fundamental needs were. What came up was the need for communication/information and #foodsovereignty.

This will be a 3 year project, that will start with me visiting and training locals to setup and maintain a basic a #community-server and #lora emergency communication between the villages. This infrastructure will assist with the further phases which will be geared towards working together with the communities to achieve food sovereignty through #agroforestry aligned with their traditional methods.

Initially we were aiming to connect the villages to the closest town, where there's Internet access. But we hit many legal barriers when planning where nodes should be placed, as the largest hill in the territory is also a natural reserve, and a sacred place for the peoples.

## Emergency communication plan

I've started [a thread on Meshtastic discourse](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/meshtastic-to-connect-remote-villages-deep-in-the-amazon) to get some tips from the community.

There are the villages we'll working with:

![balaio_link1.jpg](&y/VArytFKlVI2XazEki7Vm5ZzEHRkdW4mDwne5/Xel4=.sha256)

![balaio_link2.jpg](&66e3fo+yCuGkqGUhagyY2E1ZE55GIH0MY7Np8fIwSb4=.sha256)

The links are short ~5Km, but the vegetation and topography don't help. So I'll be working with the 433Mhz band, which should do better in this situation because of it's larger wave length.

My initial idea is to use [TTGO LoRa32](https://aliexpress.com/item/32847443952.html) with [DIY DK7ZB yagi atennas](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/dk7zb-yagi-antenna). And also [TTGO T-Beams](https://aliexpress.com/item/4001178678568.html) for mobile nodes.

Meshtastic is evolving pretty fast, and version 1.2 should come out in time for this implementation. I expect much better tools for testing and less bugs then the first experiment. [@isabela](@Gg1+3mvIraW9zkIEFCw13zy/yOLm4CFiZNZF2VDB4IE=.ed25519) and I are also working on video documentation in Portuguese, which should really help on bringing technological autonomy.

## Intranet plan

![community_setup.jpg](&Av1EDISfM9EaehmLxjpOI3d4LABBoNi3izyZx9sLUtY=.sha256)

The only access to energy they have in Balaio is thru gas generators. So we'll be taking a solar kit with 150W panel, 70Ah battery and a cheap controller. This should be enough to power the server, LoRa  radio and have some extra juice for some night lamps and phone charging.

I'll continue using a similar setup from the [last experiment](%cFBwesb+eIIVMd6vF8jptiklEr9lyWENl9e/k2tMikY=.sha256). But now with a Pi4 with 8Gb Ram and a 480Gb external HD. Now that I have a better idea of what content they might find interesting I have quite a archive of courses and indigenous videos.

Since I began working with #digital-democracy I've also learned lots, not just about #mapeo, but also about other tools. I've been slowly updating and incrementing the [community portal](https://portal-comunitario.coolab.org/). I really enjoy seeing [native-lands](https://native-land.ca/) there, I feel it'll be very empowering for them to see an indigenous world map.

All other tools have also been evolving heaps. Translations in #ahau are on the way. [ssb-hyper-blobs](%x+ZmCMQ88TXNCHer3Hd6lCr1FdXT5SEJQeBqjCXd1Ok=.sha256) is already being tested. And I started some work on a web viewer, which will make on-boarding much easier for the community.

SSB as a social network has also been evolving a lot thanks to all the work being done for #ngipointer. I'm specially excited about #ssb-browser which will also make on-boarding a lot easier.

Thanks to some financial support from #apc (which also payed for the expenses of the first experiment 🙏 ), me and [@isabela](@Gg1+3mvIraW9zkIEFCw13zy/yOLm4CFiZNZF2VDB4IE=.ed25519) are working on video tutorials in Portuguese for the most of the tools I reviewed. Hope we can finish them on time.

-----------------

I'm very excited for this next work together with the peoples of Balaio. And of course, very excited to work on the Amazon, which will be a first time. New challenges ahead. And really excited to learn and experience the amazing cultures and ways of life that dwell in such a lively region of the world.

The Krahô are responsible for protecting the largest piece of preserved savanna in brasilian territory. It's indeed very beautiful. And we were very fortunate to climb this hill, not many people have been there.

[@@](@BQXNdakpRpHqxDP2QZP/RJr95osWzW+q89MXYOZJpzw=.ed25519) and [@David Gómez](@b0e9vLp8gLDnO2EZY90IpQ2s2srEm4RYYr7VbRkLmQw=.ed25519),

My "plan" (not really a plan, more like a very vague intention) is just to do an ssb-client. I have no interest in trying to implement the server in swift, I'd rather just bundle the _go-ssb_ server in the swift app and talk to it. What I'm aiming to do is a little Swift Package that exposes an ssb client. I'm basing it in my 33% understanding of _sbotc_ and hoping for the best.

If that annoys me too much, I will try to wrap the real _sbotc_ into a library I can call from swift, probably basing it in my #project-moon-hermit which already has parts of it working anyway.

I think that fork I pushed has the necessary bits to implement a simple TCP-based SSB client library. Now, I don't know enough swift, crypto, or even SSB internals. But I'm very good at starting things and even better at not finishing them. I'd love if we could collaborate in building a simple client library, then we can either collaborate into a real client or just run wild each building their own Swift based client app. 

At the moment, I don't really care about mobile at all, and am not worried about cross-platform. All I want is an SSB client that is a proper old-style MacOS application, by that I mean native UI, AppleScript Support, menus, that kind of stuff.

The server is too hard to implement, and we have perfect fine servers available for our use. :D I'm targetting the go server since that one is easier to bundle.

Me and the #baobaxia crew have been collaborating for the past couple of months on a cultural repository platform to be used by the [Awaete peoples](https://janeraka.org). Baobaxia hasn't been updated in over 5 years, and distributes systems have evolved a lot since it first came out.

It's still a very functional system, using [@Joey Hess's](@BCM6DHYJvWzwWi1lFl2tjDXjaqyZAEmJH5ZONSpXhtc=.ed25519) amazing [Git Annex](https://git-annex.branchable.com/) project. But we've starting talking about expanding Baoxia's use-cases and joining efforts with existing projects that are going in the same direction, more specifically #ahau which is based on SSB and Hypercore.

Knowing about the project, I'd love to here your thoughts Joey, if you think it makes sense to move Baobaxia from Git Annex to distributed protocols, or maybe use them together. The pros and cons of each.

I know very little about Git Annex to be honest. So using the opportunity that we share the same digital territory, it would be awesome to hear who knows best :)

SSB has really been a life changer for me. Directly or indirectly, thru this network I met most people that I collaborate with up until this day, and the community (or at least the community that I see from my view-point) has really pushed me forward.

Unfortunately I've lost hope that SSB will flourish with the diversity that I'd like to see in the world, and have joined the circle that's waiting for private-groups in order to have spaces where we can share our own beliefs and feel safe, without having to accept dominant "truths" or lose all energy while trying to speak-up. But at least there are physical territories where I can satisfy that need for diversity and inclusion.

But maybe because it's very hard for me to get offended or angry, I have no problem coming back and opening my heart, mind and spirit to yall. And despite probably offending or making some of yall feel angry, you still try your best to be polite and understand where I come from, disagreeing in a civilized manner (that kinda pisses me off, I really enjoy the authenticity of the uncivilized lol).

It's really hard to find an online community where such level of technical discussions are happening. Philosophical ones have slowed down. Spiritual ones have become taboo.

But like many have already mentioned, there's really nowhere else to go. And there are lots of people here I hold dear and this is the only point-of-contact I have with them.

I'm happy that technically, SSB is flourishing and developing beautifully. For something that's built is a very decentralized manner, this is really amazing. Really admire the efforts of all involved.

This really is the most well structured anarchist piece of the digital world. I'd like it to go beyond that, but all is as it should be, no point in rushing things.

Been working on a methodological processes for %klnREUIw9FHajWCwzzVDwZJPjfhU9hQo2faE659b3/0=.sha256 and just found out that #manyverse and #ssb-browser both assume that a #ssb-pub runs online.

But in the case I'd like to connect people using both clients in an offline environment. I assumed I'd only have to run a pub server on the local network, but that won't work. Any ideas? [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) [@arj](@6CAxOI3f+LUOVrbAl0IemqiS7ATpQvr9Mdw9LC4+Uv0=.ed25519)

Good point, forgot it would simply show up as a local peer. Since ssb-browser doesn't have local peers, I'd have to test and see if non-internet pub works. Worst case I think a change on ssb networks configs would be needed.

Problem solved, thanks André!

# Whose Land is it Anyway? A Manual for Decolonization

Very inspiring manual on #decolonisation, containing several essays by different indigenous leaders and allies from Turtle Island (North America), more specifically Canada. My favorite quote:

> We are not only in an ecological crisis; we are in a moral human crisis.
*Melina Laboucan-Massimo*

Western civilization might come up with technical solutions to the ecological crisis. But there's definitely no technical solutions for the moral crisis it gave birth too.

- [mobi](&m29ibToHjZRO6J5n8e1TqwHizScpaHbkUmUmvCyYKaU=.sha256)
- [epub](https://www.fpse.ca/sites/default/files/news_files/Decolonization%20Handbook.epub)
- [pdf](https://fpse.ca/sites/default/files/news_files/Decolonization%20Handbook.pdf)
- [audio book](https://www.podomatic.com/podcasts/fpse/episodes/2020-06-04T10_30_20-07_00)

Alguns butts que podem interessar:
[@nonlinear](@mUNqmOd/uRBGbk9YMOzaUypf/6aPhxYI0lk6+hRyyK4=.ed25519) [@Rômulo Alves](@xr/Q/zqaEwmmd4wg8xRU1TrMLQhc9qBqNCioCqmv1vQ=.ed25519) [@SoapDog (Macbook Air)](@qv10rF4IsmxRZb7g5ekJ33EakYBpdrmV/vtP1ij5BS4=.ed25519) [@Nico Pace](@2AWm36HvcuOOcYeNgGgoybKXcMZx+COIf4/aAxJwnVI=.ed25519) [@Manoel Nascimento](@/kJQtPBb3BcYL8+cArwPGrM10o6QraBd+IQZSQek564=.ed25519) [@Pedro](@HCDhaZ8r9e92m+wGjG+l08xmfPn83n4kAKF+TG7+hpo=.ed25519)

I also have payed for a sort of title for the land I live, which of course, is stolen land. I refrain from saying that I own it, as it sounds as absurd as saying I own a piece of the sky. I loved this phrase by [Arthur Manuel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Manuel):
> You have a right to stay here as long as you recognize that it is our land and that we have a say over it.

Really resonates with me. I would much rather have First Nations have a say over this land then the invading Estate, whose primary goals are aligned with self-destructive actions of exploitation of everything in the name of "[order and progress](https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordem_e_Progresso)". Instead, as [this report by Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations](http://www.fao.org/americas/publicaciones-audio-video/forest-gov-by-indigenous/en/) concludes, indigenous peoples are responsible for actually protecting the land:

> The forests of Indigenous and tribal territories in Latin America are key for mitigating climate change and conserving biodiversity.
> ...
> Traditionally, due to a combination of factors, these forests have been much better protected than other forests in region. (Porter-Bolland et al 2012).
> ...
> In just about every country in Latin America indigenous and tribal territories have lower deforestation rates than other forest areas

And not only the land, but also the well-being of humans and non-humans. This shift of guardianship of the land would be the the first step to solving the moral crisis the world is in, and as a bonus would also start solving the environmental crisis.

# Half Earth Project

A extinção em massa em curso do mundo natural está raqueada junto as pandemias, a guerra mundial e as mudanças climáticas entre as maiores ameaças que a humanidade se impôs. Perder tanto da biodiversidade da Terra é destruir nosso patrimônio vivo e arriscar a estabilidade do planeta, hoje e para todas as gerações futuras.

Half-Earth é uma chamada para proteger metade da terra e do mar, a fim de gerenciar habitat suficiente para reverter a crise de extinção de espécies e garantir a saúde a longo prazo de nosso planeta. O Projeto Half-Earth está trazendo esse objetivo para a vida.

Subtitles on tv and movies used to distract me and i didn't like them. Then sometime many years ago i switched to liking them and now alway turn them on. I'm not sure when that happened, maybe in my early 20's riding a bus around south America where they put American movies on with the sound off and Spanish subtitles... or maybe later when I started watching more non-english language films that i got from netflix 

Either way, now i find subtitles, even in languages i know, to be essential. I've even chosen to not watch things because it isn't subtitled. 

There's now [a campaign to get parents to turn on subtitles](https://turnonthesubtitles.org/) when their kids watch videos. The theory is that presenting kids with words to read it'll cause them to do more reading without knowing it. 

I've heard speculation that nordic countries are better at english than the larger countries in europe because their media is mostly subtitled instead of dubbed. No idea if that's true, but it feels right.

I found this [real time map of starlink satellites](https://starlink.sx/) that has the ground stations so you can see which location has coverage. This is really impressive how fast and low latency these connections are. Anybody in the #scuttleverse got one yet? This should be transformational for folks wanting to work off the grid. The idea of universal world wide fast internet does make me rethink a bit of local first software. 

The power dynamics are still important, but is it better to have services you can access that you can control, like i'm fine using github because i can use my own servers or gitlab in a compatible interoperable way. Instead of the centralize way a facebook or google controls things. 

![Screen Shot 2021-04-12 at 11.16.00 AM.png](&mZHxuXZCTbHzyUj+zRmOBUFQ8rKvErq7B4qi5qeVj9k=.sha256)

They ban the shipping of glasses to Uruguay. It’d part of a monopoly created by the Luxottica mafia and local retailers. That’s why it’s so expensive. If I weren’t already planning a trip back to the US I’d order them to a friend and have them repack and ship them  in hopes they slip through customs. 

Restrictions like this are one of the more frustrating parts about living in a small isolated country. 

Of course I’m going from Uruguay, one small social democracy in the Southern Hemisphere with way more sheep than people to another,  Aotearoa. My understanding is that it’s easier to get stuff ordered online and shipped there in Aotearoa.

# #community-first portal

![moinho.app.jpg](&oEnkPkXJqy4Ljlt5hr2n6PKViLh2UdY82h6J+HdCwHk=.sha256)

Took some time this week to do some work on #moinho's community portal. With [@Nico Pace's](@2AWm36HvcuOOcYeNgGgoybKXcMZx+COIf4/aAxJwnVI=.ed25519) help I got an [online version](https://mapeo.app) and a local version of moinho.app working, both with SSL.

Through an [APC grant](%kfgG6XoeZdyrSRrqn1LJ4Yfj6r4527dMSs+yYXac7tQ=.sha256) the community worked on two local newspapers and collected information on local goods and services. The points in the map show every person/family and the goods/services they provide, with a button to message them through Whatsapp. 

The local infrastructure also has some services, that have been proven to be useful, running, such as an SSB infra (pub and browser-client), [Youtube-DL UI](https://github.com/Tzahi12345/YoutubeDL-Material), [Jellyfin](https://jellyfin.org/), [Kolibri](https://learningequality.org/kolibri/) and [Internet speed-test](https://github.com/roest01/docker-speedtest-analyser).

 ![collage.webp](&OOgYtjoAyqGQO78+UlOuh3/ouI4htCTozdwQsaQbazg=.sha256) 

## Next steps

To make SSB really inviting for the community we need a separate network, thus pubs/rooms for that network, as documented in [@arj's](@6CAxOI3f+LUOVrbAl0IemqiS7ATpQvr9Mdw9LC4+Uv0=.ed25519) [blog post](https://people.iola.dk/arj/2020/03/04/how-to-setup-a-pub-for-ssb-browser/). I've been working on Dockerfiles for easily creating rooms/pubs with different network keys: [ssb-infra](https://gitlab.com/coletivo-coolab/ssb-infra). But still not there yet.

In the future this portal app should be a #ssb-browser instance itself, so that users can post their locations, goods/services and send/receive messages all from within the app.

Very excited to get some community feedback and export this to other #communitynetworks.

Will adding [ssb-room-client](https://github.com/ssb-ngi-pointer/ssb-room-client) to ssb-browser be easy? if so I'll drop old pub/room setups and focus on [go-ssb-room](https://github.com/ssb-ngi-pointer/go-ssb-room/).
Congratulations and also your full time work on SSB will be missed.

From [SSB protocol guide](https://ssbc.github.io/scuttlebutt-protocol-guide/):

### Message format

```
 {
  "previous": "%XphMUkWQtomKjXQvFGfsGYpt69sgEY7Y4Vou9cEuJho=.sha256",
  "author": "@FCX/tsDLpubCPKKfIrw4gc+SQkHcaD17s7GI6i/ziWY=.ed25519",
  "sequence": 2,
  "timestamp": 1514517078157,
  "hash": "sha256",
  "content": {
    "type": "post",
    "text": "Second post!"
  }
}
```

- **~~previous~~**: as Arj noted, this is not strictly necessary, but how to we pass ssb-validation with this?
- **~~au~~thor**: as Andre suggested, we can use just the 4 initial chars as prefix, and re-construct them on the other side (special id LoRa messages containing the full pub key and name would have been sent before-hand)
- **sequence**: is necessary for other nodes to identify it's a message they don't have from this feed, correct?
- **~~timestamp~~**: we could use LoRa device's timestamp for this
- **~~hash~~**: we can trust all nodes to have the same
- **content**: this is the heavy part, which we'll enforce on the client-side to use 140 characters

### Signature ⚠️

> All messages in a feed are signed by that feed’s long-term secret key.

This is tricky, and can't be re-constructed on the other side without leaking the private-key and it's an extra 117 bytes, which makes it impractical, requiring at least two packets to be sent ❗


### ~~Message key~~

> A message ID is a hash of the message including signature.

This can be reconstructed on the other side **as long as we have the signature**.

 ## Use case
- **LB** (local offline network browser-user)
- **LM** (local Manyverse user)
- **LP** (local Pub)
- **IB** (Internet browser-user)
- **IP** (Internet Pub)

**LB sends a public identification message to the LoRa mesh**

```
LB --> name, full_pub_key --> SSB (about) --> compression --> LoRa mesh -->
```

All nodes eventually receive the identification message. Clients (just browser for now) pull the message from the LoRa node and reconstructs the `about` message (using trusted or already known secrets, such as Meshtastic channel), adds it to their db, and replicates it further using any means available (Bluetooth, Intranet, Internet).

**LB sends a private message to IB**

Since we don't know where the message receiver is at any given time, **LB** sends a private message to the whole LoRa mesh:

```
LB ----> boxed_msg ---> SSB ----> compression --> LoRa mesh ----> allNodes

       LB-11, LB-12 <--- SSB <------ decompression <----- LoRa node1 <-----

        LB-21 <--- SSB <------ decompression <----- LoRa node2 <-----

(Internet) <--- LM-31 <-- LP-31 <-- SSB <-- decompression <-- LoRa node3 <--
   |
   |
   |---> IP ---> IB ---> unbox
```
 All LoRa nodes eventually receives the message and stores it.

**LP-31** pulls messages from node3 decompresses the `post` message, adds to it's ssb-db, and replicates it.

**LM-31** replicates with **LP-31** through the local network.

**LM-31** goes to town and replicates with **IP**

**IB**  connects to **IP** and eventually receives the private message.

-----------

Signatures seem to be the byte-size bottleneck so far for SSB integration.

And if I understood correctly private message will have at least an additional 73 bytes, 49 bytes for each secret_box and 24 bytes for the nonce. Reducing private messages to less then 140 characters, but possible...
